From https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/Inductive-Types/#defining-the-natural-numbers:

Nat.rec.{u} :
  {motive : Nat â†’ Sort u} â†’
  (zero : motive Nat.zero) â†’
  (succ : (n : Nat) â†’ motive n â†’ motive (Nat.succ n)) â†’
  (t : Nat) â†’ motive t

The implicit argument, motive, is the codomain of the function being defined. In type theory it is common to say motive is the motive for the elimination/recursion, since it describes the kind of object we wish to construct. The next two arguments specify how to compute the zero and successor cases, as described above. They are also known as the minor premises. Finally, the t : Nat, is the input to the function. It is also known as the major premise.

Why is the t : Nat argument called the "major premise" of Nat.rec?
It's type-theoretic jargon. The major premise is the object being inducted on (here: a natural number), and the minor premises are the cases of the induction (here: zero and successor).

From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syllogism#Basic_structure:

More modern logicians allow some variation. Each of the premises has one term in common with the conclusion: in a major premise, this is the major term (i.e., the predicate of the conclusion); in a minor premise, this is the minor term (i.e., the subject of the conclusion). For example:

Major premise: All humans are mortal.
Minor premise: All Greeks are humans.
Conclusion/Consequent: All Greeks are mortal.

Each of the three distinct terms represents a category. From the example above, humans, mortal, and Greeks: mortal is the major term, and Greeks the minor term. The premises also have one term in common with each other, which is known as the middle term; in this example, humans. Both of the premises are universal, as is the conclusion.

I'm guessing some type theorists borrowed the jargon from philosophical logicians. The targets of induction (the objects being inducted on) appear to me to be closer to the minor terms (i.e., the subject of the conclusion), rather than to the major terms.
That's how it goes with logic terminology. Wait till you hear that soundness sometimes means Aâ‡’BA â‡’ BAâ‡’B and completeness Bâ‡’AB â‡’ ABâ‡’A, and other times they're swapped!
In sequent calculus this is called the "active formula". Maybe we should just call it the "recursee" since we are recursing on it.
